verses.text: This is the blessing with which Moses, the man of God, blessed the sons of Israel before his death.
verses.comment: Verse introduces the blessings, using 'man of God' phrase as in original Hebrew.

verses.text: He said: “The LORD came from Sinai, and rose upon them from Seir; He shone forth from Mount Paran, and He came with ten thousands of holy ones; at His right hand was a fiery law for them.
verses.comment: Translates 'holy myriads' as 'ten thousands of holy ones,' preserving original imagery. 'Fiery law' reflects literal Hebrew ('esh dath').

verses.text: Indeed, He loves the people; all His holy ones are in Your hand. They follow at Your feet, everyone receives Your words.
verses.comment: 'Holy ones' may refer to Israelites; translation retains ambiguity. 'They follow at Your feet' is literal from Hebrew.

verses.text: Moses commanded us a law, a possession for the assembly of Jacob.
verses.comment: 'Assembly of Jacob' is a direct phrase for Israel.

verses.text: He was king in Jeshurun, when the heads of the people gathered, the tribes of Israel together.
verses.comment: 'Jeshurun' is a poetic name for Israel; literal translation preserved.

verses.text: Let Reuben live and not die, and let his men be few.
verses.comment: Translates as in Hebrew: 'let his men be few' notes possible consequence.

verses.text: And this he said of Judah: “Hear, LORD, the voice of Judah, and bring him to his people. May his hands contend for him, and may You be a help against his adversaries.”
verses.comment: 'Voice of Judah' preserves Hebrew phrase. 'May his hands contend for him' is literal.

verses.text: Of Levi he said: “Your Thummim and Your Urim belong to Your godly one, whom You tested at Massah, with whom You challenged at the waters of Meribah;
verses.comment: 'Your godly one' refers to Levi; 'tested' and 'challenged' capture Hebrew verbs.

verses.text: who said of his father and mother, ‘I do not regard them,’ and did not acknowledge his brothers, nor recognized his own children; for they kept Your word and guarded Your covenant.
verses.comment: Retains literal phrasing; relates to Levi's zeal in Exodus 32.

verses.text: They shall teach Jacob Your judgments, and Israel Your law. They shall put incense before You, and whole burnt offerings upon Your altar.
verses.comment: Preserves division of teaching and sacrificing roles of Levi.

verses.text: Bless, LORD, his substance, and accept the work of his hands. Crush the loins of those who rise against him, and of those who hate him, that they not rise again.”
verses.comment: Follows literal 'crush the loins' language from Hebrew.

verses.text: Of Benjamin he said: “The beloved of the LORD rests securely beside Him; the LORD shelters him all day, and He dwells between his shoulders.”
verses.comment: 'Between his shoulders' is an idiom for close protection.

verses.text: Of Joseph he said: “Blessed by the LORD is his land, with precious gifts from heaven above, with dew, and with deep waters that lie below;
verses.comment: Retains reference to natural abundance.

verses.text: with choice fruits brought forth by the sun, and with rich produce yielding by the moon;
verses.comment: 'Yielding by the moon' is a literal rendering of Hebrew 'moons,' traditionally translated 'months.'

verses.text: with finest things from the ancient mountains, and excellent produce from the everlasting hills;
verses.comment: Preserves 'ancient mountains' and 'everlasting hills,' wording reflecting poetic Hebrew.

verses.text: with the best gifts of the earth and its fullness, and the favor of Him who dwelt in the bush—may these come upon the head of Joseph, upon the crown of the one distinguished among his brothers.
verses.comment: 'Him who dwelt in the bush' refers to God appearing to Moses; 'distinguished' is literal for 'separate.'

verses.text: His firstborn bull has majesty, and his horns are the horns of a wild ox; with them he will gore the peoples, all of them, to the ends of the earth; they are the ten thousands of Ephraim, and the thousands of Manasseh.”
verses.comment: 'Wild ox' is literal 'reem' in Hebrew; maintains poetic metaphors.

verses.text: Of Zebulun he said: “Rejoice, Zebulun, in your going out, and Issachar, in your tents.
verses.comment: Retains 'going out' and 'in your tents' literal phrases.

verses.text: They shall call peoples to the mountain; there they shall offer righteous sacrifices; for they draw from the abundance of the seas and the hidden treasures of the sand.”
verses.comment: Literal 'hidden treasures of the sand' may refer to coastal riches or trade.

verses.text: Of Gad he said: “Blessed is he who enlarges Gad; like a lion he dwells, and he tears the arm and the crown of the head.
verses.comment: Retains original imagery comparing Gad to a lion.

verses.text: He chose the best for himself, for there the leader’s portion was reserved; he came with the heads of the people, he executed the LORD’s justice and His ordinances for Israel.”
verses.comment: References Gad’s settlement east of the Jordan.

verses.text: Of Dan he said: “Dan is a lion’s cub; he leaps forth from Bashan.”
verses.comment: 'Leaps forth from Bashan' possibly refers to Dan's later territory.

verses.text: Of Naphtali he said: “O Naphtali, satisfied with favor, and full of the blessing of the LORD, take possession of the sea and the south.”
verses.comment: 'Sea and the south' likely refers to territory; literal translation preserved.

verses.text: Of Asher he said: “Blessed above sons be Asher; let him be favored by his brothers, and let him dip his foot in oil.
verses.comment: 'Dip his foot in oil' is literal, possibly refers to agricultural abundance.

verses.text: Your bars shall be iron and bronze, and as your days, so shall your strength be.
verses.comment: 'Bars' refers to gates or territory; 'strength' literally 'rest.'

verses.text: There is none like God, O Jeshurun, who rides the heavens to your help, and in His majesty on the clouds.
verses.comment: Preserves poetic description of God as 'rider of heavens.'

verses.text: The eternal God is your dwelling place, and underneath are the everlasting arms. He thrust out the enemy before you and said, ‘Destroy!’
verses.comment: Translates 'dwelling place' (Heb. 'me'onah') as 'refuge.'

verses.text: So Israel dwelt in safety, Jacob lived alone, in a land of grain and wine, where his heavens drop down dew.
verses.comment: 'Jacob lived alone' means securely and undisturbed.

verses.text: Blessed are you, O Israel! Who is like you, a people saved by the LORD, the shield of your help, and the sword of your triumph! Your enemies shall cringe before you, and you shall tread on their high places.”
verses.comment: Retains 'cringe' and 'tread on their high places'—literal rendering from Hebrew.
